elements.content: The structural diversity of Co­(II) metal centers is known to influence their physicochemical properties. A novel two-dimensional (2D) Co­(II)-MOF {[Co5(HL)4(dpp)2(H2O)2(μ-OH)2]·21H2O}n has been designed and synthesized by adopting a mixed-ligand strategy, using 1,3-di­(4-pyridyl)­propane (dpp) colinker with a flexible spacer H3L (H3L: 5-(2 carboxybenzyloxy)­isophthalic acid). Co­(II)-MOF features a 2D network, which is further interpenetrated among the equivalent sets and therefore results in a 3D supramolecular network. Topologically, the entire network can be viewed as a (3,4,8)-connected three-nodal net with the extended point symbol of {4.5.7}­4­{412.52.710.94}­{52.8.92.10}­2, duly assigned to the novel topological type smm 2. The functional utility of Co­(II)-MOF is demonstrated by employing it toward oxygen evolution reaction (OER) in a photoelectrochemical cell, exhibiting appreciable photocurrents of up to 5.89 mA/cm2 when used as an anode in a photoelectrochemical cell, while also displaying encouraging electrocatalytic currents of 9.32 mA/cm2 (at 2.01 V vs RHE) for the OER. Moreover, detailed electrochemical impedance spectroscopy studies confirm enhanced charge-transfer kinetics and improved conductivity under illumination with minimal effect of interfacial phenomena. This work provides a reference for the expanding field of research into applications of MOF materials and establishes MOF materials as favorable candidates for sustainable and efficient design of electrodes for water splitting.

The functional utility of Co(II)-MOF is demonstrated by employing it toward oxygen evolution reaction (OER) in a photoelectrochemical cell, exhibiting appreciable photocurrents of up to 5.89 mA/cm2 when used as an anode in a photoelectrochemical cell, while also displaying encouraging electrocatalytic currents of 9.32 mA/cm2 (at 2.01 V vs RHE) for the OER. elements.content: Increasing energy demands and severe environmental changes resulting from extensive combustion of traditional fossil fuels have stimulated considerable attention toward exploring clean and sustainable energy sources as alternatives. Hydrogen seems to be an ideal and clean energy source and is considered as a prime energy carrier for the future on the basis of its nontoxicity, high gravimetric energy density, and ideal combustion efficiency. Electrochemical water splitting, a combination of its two half-reactions, i.e., hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER) to generate hydrogen and oxygen, respectively, is understood to be the most favorable approach to produce clean hydrogen fuel and has potential to deliver next-generation energy devices. To make next-generation energy devices, the development of effective catalysts to enhance the kinetics of both reactions (HER and OER) is essential. Precious noble-metal-based catalysts, i.e., platinum (Pt) and metal oxides (RuOx and IrOx), exhibit active performance for the HER and OER, respectively. However, the high cost, limited pH range, poor durability, and scarcity of these metals severely limits their widespread adoption in industrial applications. Consequently, great efforts have been devoted to develop cost-effective catalysts with good activity, durability, and stability using earth-abundant elements. From this perspective, different inorganic nanomaterials and functional molecular materials have been investigated for water splitting, from transition-metal chalcogenides, carbides, nitrides, phosphides to carbon materials and also clusters from molecules to single-atom levels. Nevertheless, it is still challenging to develop more efficient electrocatalysts for overall water splitting. Pioneering research efforts from Fujishima and Honda led to the discovery of solar-assisted water splitting, in which photons are used as an energy source to reduce or remove the electrical input required to accelerate the OER and/or HER in electrochemical cells comprising of electrodes made of suitable materials. However, the development of a suitable photocatalyst has posed a number of challenges for researchers due to a number of requirements, including good pH stability, suitable band gap (between 1.6 and 3.2 eV), fast charge transport kinetics, and minimal electron–hole recombination. In this respect, efforts have been made to develop a number of catalysts but many of them pose the problem of high cost and/or poor stability.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Increasing energy demands and severe environmental changes resulting from extensive combustion of traditional fossil fuels have stimulated considerable attention toward exploring clean and sustainable energy sources as alternatives. Hydrogen seems to be an ideal and clean energy source and is considered as a prime energy carrier for the future on the basis of its nontoxicity, high gravimetric energy density, and ideal combustion efficiency. Electrochemical water splitting, a combination of its two half-reactions, i.e., hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER) to generate hydrogen and oxygen, respectively, is understood to be the most favorable approach to produce clean hydrogen fuel and has potential to deliver next-generation energy devices. To make next-generation energy devices, the development of effective catalysts to enhance the kinetics of both reactions (HER and OER) is essential. Precious noble-metal-based catalysts, i.e., platinum (Pt) and metal oxides (RuOx and IrOx), exhibit active performance for the HER and OER, respectively. However, the high cost, limited pH range, poor durability, and scarcity of these metals severely limits their widespread adoption in industrial applications. Consequently, great efforts have been devoted to develop cost-effective catalysts with good activity, durability, and stability using earth-abundant elements. From this perspective, different inorganic nanomaterials and functional molecular materials have been investigated for water splitting, from transition-metal chalcogenides, carbides, nitrides, phosphides to carbon materials and also clusters from molecules to single-atom levels. Nevertheless, it is still challenging to develop more efficient electrocatalysts for overall water splitting. Pioneering research efforts from Fujishima and Honda led to the discovery of solar-assisted water splitting, in which photons are used as an energy source to reduce or remove the electrical input required to accelerate the OER and/or HER in electrochemical cells comprising of electrodes made of suitable materials. However, the development of a suitable photocatalyst has posed a number of challenges for researchers due to a number of requirements, including good pH stability, suitable band gap (between 1.6 and 3.2 eV), fast charge transport kinetics, and minimal electron-hole recombination. In this respect, efforts have been made to develop a number of catalysts but many of them pose the problem of high cost and/or poor stability.

elements.content: Currently, metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) designed from metal ions or clusters bridged by organic ligands have emerged as a new class of crystalline materials with porous characteristics. They have attracted widespread attention due to their fascinating structural diversity and tailorability, high surface area, and tremendous potential for practical applications, including energy conversion and storage. To date, a large number of MOFs exhibit good electrocatalytic activities and are found to be stable against chemical corrosion and bubbles’ attack. However, the majority of MOF-based electrocatalysts demonstrates limited efficiencies because of their lower mass permeability and poor electrical conductivity. In a bulk MOF, the active sites are exposed toward the pores or channels that are susceptible to interference by the organic linkers and thus limit the accessibility for the electrolytes. To overcome such shortcomings, 2D MOFs with high surface areas have been used, where mostly active metal sites are directly exposed to electrolytes. Such 2D MOFs are advantageous for electronic conductivity due to fast electron transfer, easier mass transport, and facilitated interaction with coordinately unsaturated surface metal sites. The synthesis of catalytically active 2D MOFs with controlled morphology remains a growing field with many investigations ongoing. Moreover, the existing reports on photocatalytic studies of MOFs are focused on heavy metal reduction, CO2 reduction, dye degradation, and industrially relevant reactions with only a few reports on use as photoelectrodes, cocatalysts, or sensitizers in solar cells and/or photoelectrochemical cells.

elements.content: Keeping all of the above aspects in mind, we have synthesized a novel 2D Co­(II)-MOF using mixed-ligand systems under hydrothermal conditions. It is expected that the combination of novel topographic features with transition-metal centers in 2D-MOF will deliver appreciable results for the OER via both photo- and electrocatalytic mechanisms. Our results suggest good photocatalytic activity for water splitting, along with appreciable electrocatalytic currents for the oxygen evolution reaction for the designed Co­(II)-MOF in a common 1 M Na2SO4 electrolyte, which was selected on the basis of stability and with a view to consider a reduced cost of operation and environmentally benign design.

Experimental Section

Chemicals and Instrumentation

The materials, physical measurement, and crystallographic analysis are described in the Supporting Information. The crystallographic data of Co(II)-MOF has been deposited with the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Center, and the CCDC number is 1888033.

elements.content: The ligand H3L was synthesized in several steps as reported earlier, and dpp was used as a commercial source. Details of the synthetic procedure and its characterization are given in the Supporting Information.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of the Ligands

The ligand H3L was synthesized in several steps as reported earlier, and dpp was used as a commercial source. Details of the synthetic procedure and its characterization are given in the Supporting Information.

elements.content: Co­(II)-MOF was synthesized by using a mixture of H3L (0.020 g, 0.06 mmol), 1,3-bis­(4-pyridyl)­propane (dpp) (0.010 g, 0.06 mmol), and CoCl2·6H2O (0.056 g, 0.18 mmol) in water (3 mL) and 0.1 mL of 1 M NaOH solution. These constituents were packed in a Teflon-lined autoclave and heated under high pressure to 100 °C for 3 days and with subsequent cooling to room temperature at the rate of 1 °C/min. The block-shaped, purple crystals of Co­(II)-MOF were filtered and repeatedly subjected to water and acetone washes and air-dried (yield = 78%). IR (cm–1): 3417 (br), 2935 (m, br), 1712 (m), 1624 (s), 1566 (s), 1452 (m), 1373 (s), 1258 (m), 1219 (m), 1129 (m), 1028 (s), 785 (s), 713 (s), 619 (m), 583 (m), 504 (m) (Figure S7).
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of (Co(II)-MOF)

 Co(II)-MOF was synthesized by using a mixture of H3L (0.020 g, 0.06 mmol), 1,3-bis(4-pyridyl)propane (dpp) (0.010 g, 0.06 mmol), and CoCl2⋅6H2O (0.056 g, 0.18 mmol) in water (3 mL) and 0.1 mL of 1 M NaOH solution. These constituents were packed in a Teflon-lined autoclave and heated under high pressure to 100 °C for 3 days and with subsequent cooling to room temperature at the rate of 1 °C/min. The block-shaped, purple crystals of Co(II)-MOF were filtered and repeatedly subjected to water and acetone washes and air-dried (yield = 78%). IR (cm-1): 3417 (br), 2935 (m, br), 1712 (m), 1624 (s), 1566 (s), 1452 (m), 1373 (s), 1258 (m), 1219 (m), 1129 (m), 1028 (s), 785 (s), 713 (s), 619 (m), 583 (m), 504 (m) (Figure S7).

elements.content: Electrochemical measurements were performed on a standard three-electrode photoelectrochemical cell comprised of Ag/AgCl reference electrode, platinum counter electrode, and Co­(II)-MOF deposited on GCE surface (henceforth called as Co-MOF/GCE) through drop cast method as the working electrode. For the J–V (current density–voltage) tests, a calibrated LED light source with irradiation power equivalent to 1000 W/m2 was utilized to measure the photocurrent. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) was performed with a frequency range of 1 Hz to 100 000 Hz using the same electrochemical cell as previously described. The electrochemical workstation used was an AUTOLAB PGSTAT 204N.
elements.clean_text:
Electrochemical Measurements

Electrochemical measurements were performed on a standard three-electrode photoelectrochemical cell comprised of Ag/AgCl reference electrode, platinum counter electrode, and Co(II)-MOF deposited on GCE surface (henceforth called as Co-MOF/GCE) through drop cast method as the working electrode. For the J-V (current density-voltage) tests, a calibrated LED light source with irradiation power equivalent to 1000 W/m2 was utilized to measure the photocurrent. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) was performed with a frequency range of 1 Hz to 100000 Hz using the same electrochemical cell as previously described. The electrochemical workstation used was an AUTOLAB PGSTAT 204N.

elements.content: A novel mixed-ligand-derived Co­(II)-MOF was synthesized using a facile hydrothermal synthesis method, as previously described. The method of synthesis is described in and is based on the concept of nucleation under high pressure. After synthesis, the as-derived crystals are thoroughly analyzed with single-crystal X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis and thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) and afterward, these crystals are ground to a fine powder for scanning electron microscopy (SEM), powder X-ray diffraction (P-XRD), and UV–vis spectroscopy. For electrochemical experiments, the ground powders were deposited on the surface of a glassy carbon electrode (GCE) through drop casting. The modified GCE, now called as Co-MOF/GCE, was used for subsequent electrochemical characterization (details in the Supporting Information).
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

A novel mixed-ligand-derived Co(II)-MOF was synthesized using a facile hydrothermal synthesis method, as previously described. The method of synthesis is described in  and is based on the concept of nucleation under high pressure. After synthesis, the as-derived crystals are thoroughly analyzed with single-crystal X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis and thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) and afterward, these crystals are ground to a fine powder for scanning electron microscopy (SEM), powder X-ray diffraction (P-XRD), and UV-vis spectroscopy. For electrochemical experiments, the ground powders were deposited on the surface of a glassy carbon electrode (GCE) through drop casting. The modified GCE, now called as Co-MOF/GCE, was used for subsequent electrochemical characterization (details in the Supporting Information).

elements.content: The single-crystal X-ray analysis revealed that Co-MOF crystallizes in the orthorhombic Cccm space group. The asymmetric unit is composed of three crystallographically independent Co­(II) ions with different occupancies, i.e., quarter occupancy by Co1 and half occupancies by Co2 and Co3, one HL2– ligand, half dpp ligand, one bridged hydroxide ion, and one coordinated water molecule (a). Co1 is coordinated with four O atoms from individual HL2– in bridging mode and two bridging hydroxide (μ2-OH) ions, resulting in a CoO6 octahedral geometry (b). Similarly, Co3 shows CoO6 octahedral geometry by coordinating with four O atoms of individual HL2– in bridging and ambidentate modes equally along with one μ2-OH ion and one water molecule (b). In the case of Co2, coordination occurs through four O atoms of two different HL2– in chelating mode and two N atoms of two individual dpp linkers, exhibiting a CoO4N2 distorted octahedral geometry (b).
elements.clean_text:
Structural Analysis of Co(II)-MOF

The single-crystal X-ray analysis revealed that Co-MOF crystallizes in the orthorhombic Cccm space group. The asymmetric unit is composed of three crystallographically independent Co(II) ions with different occupancies, i.e., quarter occupancy by Co1 and half occupancies by Co2 and Co3, one HL2- ligand, half dpp ligand, one bridged hydroxide ion, and one coordinated water molecule (a). Co1 is coordinated with four O atoms from individual HL2- in bridging mode and two bridging hydroxide (μ2-OH) ions, resulting in a CoO6 octahedral geometry (b). Similarly, Co3 shows CoO6 octahedral geometry by coordinating with four O atoms of individual HL2- in bridging and ambidentate modes equally along with one μ2-OH ion and one water molecule (b). In the case of Co2, coordination occurs through four O atoms of two different HL2- in chelating mode and two N atoms of two individual dpp linkers, exhibiting a CoO4N2 distorted octahedral geometry (b).

elements.content: Perspective view of (a) asymmetric unit and (b) coordination environment of Co­(II) ions, in Co­(II)-MOF. (c) The coordination mode of the carboxylate linker in Co­(II)-MOF.

elements.content: The ligand H3L exhibits HL2– species, in which two carboxylate groups are fully deprotonated, and one remains as it is (c), which is consistent with the IR results (Figure S7). Co―O distances are in the range 2.015(4)–2.232(5) Å, and the Co―N distance is 2.076(5) Å, which is found to be similar to values reported in the literature. Twelve carboxylate and carboxylic acid groups from six HL2– moieties, employing the syn–syn coordination of bridging and ambidentate carboxylate group, connect Co1 and Co3 together, generating a trinuclear Co cluster, whereas the chelating carboxylate groups coordinated with Co2 in a mononuclear fashion produce large channels of 12.929(2) Å × 15.619(2) Å dimensions [the distance refers to Co to Co metal ions, solvent molecules ignored] (Figure S8). The trinuclear Co cluster units and mononuclear Co ions are further linked together by HL2– linkers and dpp colinkers, resulting in a 2D porous framework with a large number of channels running between the a- and b- axis (b), where the pore surface is lined with O atoms of carboxylate group and μ2-OH as well as Co metal ions (a,b). Also, numerous disordered water molecules fill the channels, which could not be well assigned from the difference map. The presence of such disordered water molecules is reported to enhance catalytic activity and electrical conductivity. The number of guest water molecules (21 H2O molecules per asymmetric unit) was further confirmed from thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) (Figure S9). The total solvent-accessible void volume is in good accordance with the PLATON-calculated solvent-accessible void volume and estimated to be 27.10% (2959.7 out of 10 911 Å3) through TGA.

elements.content: The most striking feature in Co­(II)-MOF is the unprecedented 2D + 2D → 3D self-interpenetrated array constructed from Co­(II) and HL2– and dpp ligands. As shown in a, HL2– and dpp ligands link Co1, Co2, and Co3 together to form 2D sheets. By sharing the Co2 and dpp colinkers, each of the 2D sheets are not isolated but rather incorporated together through interpenetration, resulting in a 3D supramolecular self-interpenetrated array (b,c), where all of the 2D sheets are nearly orthogonal to each other and the associated channels too (Figure S10a,b). As shown in the Figure S10c, the self-interpenetrating array contains one more type of channel along the c axis, representing the porosity along each axis in the framework (Figure S10d).
elements.clean_text: The most striking feature in Co(II)-MOF is the unprecedented 2D + 2D → 3D self-interpenetrated array constructed from Co(II) and HL2- and dpp ligands. As shown in a, HL2- and dpp ligands link Co1, Co2, and Co3 together to form 2D sheets. By sharing the Co2 and dpp colinkers, each of the 2D sheets are not isolated but rather incorporated together through interpenetration, resulting in a 3D supramolecular self-interpenetrated array (b,c), where all of the 2D sheets are nearly orthogonal to each other and the associated channels too (Figure S10a,b). As shown in the Figure S10c, the self-interpenetrating array contains one more type of channel along the c axis, representing the porosity along each axis in the framework (Figure S10d).

elements.content: In the field of crystal engineering, topology (using Topos software) is an important tool for simplifying complicated supramolecular networks. The topological analysis of Co­(II)-MOF shows two types of metal nodes present in the network, i.e., eight-connected and four-connected nodes represented by trinuclear and mononuclear Co centers, respectively. Additionally, the tritopic carboxylate ligand acts as a three-connected node, whereas the dpp colinker is present in its simplified form, i.e., 1, 2-connector. Therefore, the entire network can be viewed as a (3,4,8)-connected three-nodal net with the extended point symbol {4.5.7}­4­{412.52.710.94}­{52.8.92.10}­2, which is assigned to the novel topological type smm 2 in Topos Pro database ().

elements.content: The SEM images (Figure S11) show clusters of aggregated flakes of Co­(II)-MOF, with each feature (flake) size of approximately 300–500 nm. The presence of well-defined facets and smooth edges is an indicator of good crystallinity. A previous study has noted the dependence of the feature size on enhanced reaction kinetics in electrochemical cells, with smaller sizes being favored for enhanced performance.
elements.clean_text: The SEM images (Figure S11) show clusters of aggregated flakes of Co(II)-MOF, with each feature (flake) size of approximately 300-500 nm. elements.content: As shown in Figure S12, the powder X-ray diffraction patterns (P-XRD) are observed to have some extra peaks when compared with simulated patterns from the single-crystal X-ray data for Co­(II)-MOF. These extra peaks are attributed to the presence of crystal defects and guest molecules inside the framework. The high level of crystallinity observed is favorable for conductivity measurements. The thermal stability of Co­(II)-MOF was established by its TGA (Figure S9), where the thermogram shows a weight loss of 16.60% (calcd. 16.40%) due to the removal of lattice and coordinated water molecules within the temperature range of 30–180 °C. The framework is stable at least up to 280 °C, and after that the framework starts to collapse.
elements.clean_text:
Purity and Thermal stability of Co(II)-MOF

As shown in Figure S12, the powder X-ray diffraction patterns (P-XRD) are observed to have some extra peaks when compared with simulated patterns from the single-crystal X-ray data for Co(II)-MOF. These extra peaks are attributed to the presence of crystal defects and guest molecules inside the framework. The high level of crystallinity observed is favorable for conductivity measurements. The thermal stability of Co(II)-MOF was established by its TGA (Figure S9), where the thermogram shows a weight loss of 16.60% (calcd. 16.40%) due to the removal of lattice and coordinated water molecules within the temperature range of 30-180 °C. The framework is stable at least up to 280 °C, and after that the framework starts to collapse.

elements.content: The absorbance spectrum for UV–vis is presented in . The spectrum shows absorbance peaks at 563 and 520 nm, respectively, corresponding to a band gap of 2.2–2.4 eV. The peaks also correspond to characteristic bands corresponding to d–d transitions of Co­(II)-based compounds. Using Tauc’s relations (Supporting Information), we found two discontinuities in the plot of d­[ln­(αhv)/d­(hv)] (where α is the absorption coefficient and hv refers to the energy) on y axis and energy E (=hv) on the x axis, corresponding to the two transitions observed in the UV–vis absorption plot with maxima of 1.99 and 2.22 eV, respectively (). To determine the nature of these transitions, we plotted (αhv)1/n against the energy of absorption (Figure S13), where n represents the nature of the transition. After comparing the linear intercepts of the plots with the discontinuity plot of , we found that the absorption maxima at 1.99 eV refers to an indirect allowed transition whereas the absorption maxima at 2.22 eV refers to a direct forbidden transition. Both types of transitions are known to contribute to the conductivity of the material. Since the d-orbitals tend to be located in the midgap energy levels for transition-metal ions, it is theorized that the photogenerated holes of d-valence band can initiate better coordination of OH– or H2O to the semiconductor surface and facilitate fast charge transfer, resulting in photoactivity for oxidation reactions. Previously, an absorption peak at 330 nm has been reported for the linker. However, this peak does not play any significant role in catalytic activity or conduction mechanism for the purpose of photoelectrochemical water splitting due to the visible light wavelength range used for the light source.
elements.clean_text:
UV-Vis Spectroscopy of Co(II)-MOF

The absorbance spectrum for UV-vis is presented in . The spectrum shows absorbance peaks at 563 and 520 nm, respectively, corresponding to a band gap of 2.2-2.4 eV. The peaks also correspond to characteristic bands corresponding to d-d transitions of Co(II)-based compounds. Using Tauc's relations (Supporting Information), we found two discontinuities in the plot of d[ln(αhv)/d(hv)] (where α is the absorption coefficient and hv refers to the energy) on y axis and energy E (=hv) on the x axis, corresponding to the two transitions observed in the UV-vis absorption plot with maxima of 1.99 and 2.22 eV, respectively (). To determine the nature of these transitions, we plotted (αhv)1/n  against the energy of absorption (Figure S13), where n represents the nature of the transition. After comparing the linear intercepts of the plots with the discontinuity plot of , we found that the absorption maxima at 1.99 eV refers to an indirect allowed transition whereas the absorption maxima at 2.22 eV refers to a direct forbidden transition. Both types of transitions are known to contribute to the conductivity of the material. Since the d-orbitals tend to be located in the midgap energy levels for transition-metal ions, it is theorized that the photogenerated holes of d-valence band can initiate better coordination of OH- or H2O to the semiconductor surface and facilitate fast charge transfer, resulting in photoactivity for oxidation reactions. Previously, an absorption peak at 330 nm has been reported for the linker. However, this peak does not play any significant role in catalytic activity or conduction mechanism for the purpose of photoelectrochemical water splitting due to the visible light wavelength range used for the light source.

elements.content: The interesting results from UV–vis analysis suggested absorption bands in the visible light spectrum, which encouraged us to investigate Co­(II)-MOF for photoelectrochemical cells, specifically as an anode for the OER. shows the J–V characteristics of the Co-MOF/GCE electrode, as prepared by the method mentioned earlier. The J–V curve displays an onset potential of 1.65 V vs relative hydrogen electrode (RHE), and the photocurrent increases as we raise the voltage, nearing a maximum of 5.89 mA/cm2 at 2.01 V vs RHE. However, it is interesting to note that Co­(II)-MOF is quite active even as an electrocatalyst for the anodic (oxygen evolution) reaction. The onset potential and electrocatalytic and photocatalytic currents at various applied voltages are comparable to or better than those in several other studies using a wide range of catalysts, such as WO3/α-Fe2O3, roughened porous platinum, nickel phosphide nanoparticles, three-dimensional graphene heterostructures, metal-treated nanoporous carbon, graphene/MWCNT-based nanostructures, metal precursor-treated WO3, Co3O4 hollow polyhedrons, tridoped (B, N, S) GO/CoO composites, and LaMnO3–carbon nanofiber composite and a detailed comparison is given in . It is observed that the Co­(II)-MOF displays comparable performance (using GCE electrode) to several nanostructured powders and thin films using FTO/ITO-coated glass as the substrate, which is reported to have better performance due to higher electronegativity of fluorine and iodine in comparison to that of carbon, allowing the substrate to act as an electron sink. Photocurrents are generally observed in addition to already existing electrocatalytic currents, and it is observed that even without appropriate illumination, Co-MOF/GCE is competitive as an electrocatalyst for the OER. If only the photocatalytic current is considered, this current still compares well with the base electrocatalytic current of the other reported OER catalysts in . The photocurrent is in line with expectations from the absorbance spectrum of UV–vis spectroscopy defined earlier, wherein absorbance peaks at 563 and 520 nm were observed. Under illumination, the Co­(II)-MOF-coated GCE meets a benchmark anodic current of 10 mA/cm2 at 1.9645 V vs RHE, giving an overpotential of 734.5 mV over the standard water oxidation potential of 1.23 V. The current–voltage curve of Co­(II)-MOF under illumination has a linear region, which starts at approximately 1.65 V vs RHE and an exponential region, which starts at approximately 1.84 V vs RHE. A Tafel analysis of the exponential part of this photocurrent shows a high Tafel slope of 415 mV (Figure S14), which suggests that factors other than reaction charge-transfer kinetics are contributing to the high photocurrent, and this may be due to the fact that Co­(II)-MOF contains significant porosity. However, the porous nature may also promote increased light absorption. On the other hand, we do observe a significant electrocatalytic current also for the OER, which reaches up to 9.32 mA/cm2 at 2 V vs RHE. The favorable conduction and photocurrents tend to be influenced by the band gap falling in the optimal range of 1.6–2.4 eV, and the layered nature of the structure is conducive for charge transfer. The photocurrent was found to retain 82.29% of its original value after 1 h when tested in a 3-electrode cell with a pH 10.5 (1 M Na2SO4 adjusted with NaOH) electrolyte and a 3-electrode electrochemical cell comprising of Ag/AgCl reference electrode (tested at 2 V vs RHE), Pt counter electrode, and Co-MOF/GCE as the working electrode (Figure S15). Over multiple measurements, the error margin for the photocurrent and the electrocatalytic current was found to be within the experimental error margin of ±5% (Figure S16). Moreover, the Faradaic efficiency of the OER under illumination was found to be 91.9% (Supporting Information).

To further investigate the photocurrent and the phenomena surrounding it, we recorded the electrochemical impedance spectrum in dark conditions as well as under illumination. A single semicircle shape is observed in the Nyquist plot, which is modeled by a single equivalent RC element in series with resistance. Due to the depressed nature of the semicircle with its center below the X axis zero position, a constant phase element (CPE) is used instead of capacitance, as the element displays mixed characteristics. The presence of a single semicircle in the complex plot suggests only one contact resistance (that of the material and the glassy carbon electrode surface) and the existence of a single polarization relaxation process due to the effective contribution of the crystal interior. Under illumination, the Co-MOF/GCE electrode tends to display a Nyquist Plot that is offset from the equivalent graph. displays the values obtained by fitting of the electrochemical circuit shown in , and the value of ϕ indicates distributive behavior and inhomogeneity in the sample. Each interface is associated with a charge-transfer process with an appropriate resistance mapped to it, but in this case, the only interface is between that of the deposited Co-MOF and the glassy carbon electrode active surface; hence, a single charge-transfer resistance is used for the model. From the , it is clear that the charge-transfer resistance decreases under illumination, and also the series resistance, possibly due to the enhanced conductivity of the active layer (i.e., Co-MOF) under visible light irradiation. However, it is observed that under illumination, the displacement of the Nyquist plot from the origin increases, which is attributed to an ohmic drop caused by the release of gas bubbles inside the electrochemical cell during the OER.

In this study, we have reported the synthesis of a novel 2D Co­(II)-MOF {[Co5(HL)4(dpp)2(H2O)2(μ-OH)2]·21H2O}n through a facile, mixed-ligand strategy. The as-synthesized MOF displays good conductivity and shows ability to absorb photonic energy and utilize it toward the oxygen evolution reaction in a photoelectrochemical cell. A remarkable photocurrent of 5.89 mA/cm2 is noted with a good electrocatalytic current of 9.32 mA/cm2 (at 2.01 V vs RHE). The observed characteristics lead us to believe that a rational design of transition-metal MOFs with unique topology and layered structures of ligands can lead to enhancement of catalytic activity toward the oxygen evolution reaction.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In this study, we have reported the synthesis of a novel 2D Co(II)-MOF {[Co5(HL)4(dpp)2(H2O)2(μ-OH)2]⋅21H2O}n through a facile, mixed-ligand strategy. The as-synthesized MOF displays good conductivity and shows ability to absorb photonic energy and utilize it toward the oxygen evolution reaction in a photoelectrochemical cell. A remarkable photocurrent of 5.89 mA/cm2 is noted with a good electrocatalytic current of 9.32 mA/cm2 (at 2.01 V vs RHE). The observed characteristics lead us to believe that a rational design of transition-metal MOFs with unique topology and layered structures of ligands can lead to enhancement of catalytic activity toward the oxygen evolution reaction.

cln_elements.content: Co­(II)-MOF was synthesized by using a mixture of H3L (0.020 g, 0.06 mmol), 1,3-bis­(4-pyridyl)­propane (dpp) (0.010 g, 0.06 mmol), and CoCl2·6H2O (0.056 g, 0.18 mmol) in water (3 mL) and 0.1 mL of 1 M NaOH solution. These constituents were packed in a Teflon-lined autoclave and heated under high pressure to 100 °C for 3 days and with subsequent cooling to room temperature at the rate of 1 °C/min. The block-shaped, purple crystals of Co­(II)-MOF were filtered and repeatedly subjected to water and acetone washes and air-dried (yield = 78%). IR (cm–1): 3417 (br), 2935 (m, br), 1712 (m), 1624 (s), 1566 (s), 1452 (m), 1373 (s), 1258 (m), 1219 (m), 1129 (m), 1028 (s), 785 (s), 713 (s), 619 (m), 583 (m), 504 (m) (Figure S7).
cln_elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of (Co(II)-MOF)

 Co(II)-MOF was synthesized by using a mixture of H3L (0.020 g, 0.06 mmol), 1,3-bis(4-pyridyl)propane (dpp) (0.010 g, 0.06 mmol), and CoCl2⋅6H2O (0.056 g, 0.18 mmol) in water (3 mL) and 0.1 mL of 1 M NaOH solution. These constituents were packed in a Teflon-lined autoclave and heated under high pressure to 100 °C for 3 days and with subsequent cooling to room temperature at the rate of 1 °C/min. The block-shaped, purple crystals of Co(II)-MOF were filtered and repeatedly subjected to water and acetone washes and air-dried (yield = 78%). IR (cm-1): 3417 (br), 2935 (m, br), 1712 (m), 1624 (s), 1566 (s), 1452 (m), 1373 (s), 1258 (m), 1219 (m), 1129 (m), 1028 (s), 785 (s), 713 (s), 619 (m), 583 (m), 504 (m) (Figure S7).

cln_elements.content:
The ligand H3L exhibits HL2– species, in which two carboxylate groups are fully deprotonated, and one remains as it is (c), which is consistent with the IR results (Figure S7). Co―O distances are in the range 2.015(4)–2.232(5) Å, and the Co―N distance is 2.076(5) Å, which is found to be similar to values reported in the literature. Twelve carboxylate and carboxylic acid groups from six HL2– moieties, employing the syn–syn coordination of bridging and ambidentate carboxylate group, connect Co1 and Co3 together, generating a trinuclear Co cluster, whereas the chelating carboxylate groups coordinated with Co2 in a mononuclear fashion produce large channels of 12.929(2) Å × 15.619(2) Å dimensions [the distance refers to Co to Co metal ions, solvent molecules ignored] (Figure S8). The trinuclear Co cluster units and mononuclear Co ions are further linked together by HL2– linkers and dpp colinkers, resulting in a 2D porous framework with a large number of channels running between the a- and b- axis (b), where the pore surface is lined with O atoms of carboxylate group and μ2-OH as well as Co metal ions (a,b). Also, numerous disordered water molecules fill the channels, which could not be well assigned from the difference map. The presence of such disordered water molecules is reported to enhance catalytic activity and electrical conductivity. The number of guest water molecules (21 H2O molecules per asymmetric unit) was further confirmed from thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) (Figure S9). The total solvent-accessible void volume is in good accordance with the PLATON-calculated solvent-accessible void volume and estimated to be 27.10% (2959.7 out of 10 911 Å3) through TGA.

Purity and Thermal stability of Co­(II)-MOF

As shown in Figure S12, the powder X-ray diffraction patterns (P-XRD) are observed to have some extra peaks when compared with simulated patterns from the single-crystal X-ray data for Co­(II)-MOF. These extra peaks are attributed to the presence of crystal defects and guest molecules inside the framework. The high level of crystallinity observed is favorable for conductivity measurements. The thermal stability of Co­(II)-MOF was established by its TGA (Figure S9), where the thermogram shows a weight loss of 16.60% (calcd. 16.40%) due to the removal of lattice and coordinated water molecules within the temperature range of 30–180 °C. The framework is stable at least up to 280 °C, and after that the framework starts to collapse.

Purity and Thermal stability of Co(II)-MOF

As shown in Figure S12, the powder X-ray diffraction patterns (P-XRD) are observed to have some extra peaks when compared with simulated patterns from the single-crystal X-ray data for Co(II)-MOF. | material for active electrode | synthesis method | substrate | electrolyte[^+] | catalyst type | observed onset potential | observed current (mA/cm^2) | reference |
|--------------------------------|-------------------|-----------|-----------------|---------------|--------------------------|-----------------------------|-----------|
| Co3O4 hollow polyhedrons | thermal oxidation of ZIF-67 | glassy carbon electrode | 1 M KOH | electrocatalyst | 1.62 V vs RHE | 5 | [5] |
| WO3/α-Fe2O3 thin films | sputter deposition under high vacuum | FTO | 0.5 M Na2SO4 | photocatalyst | 0.73 V vs RHE | 0.84 | [46] |
| metal–metal oxide (Ni, Co)/3DHPG (hierarchical porous graphene) | exchange/activation from cation exchange resin | glassy carbon electrode | 1 M KOH | electrocatalyst | 1.52 V vs RHE (Ni-NiO/3DHPG) 1.59 V vs RHE (Co-CoO/3DHPG) 1.67 V vs RHE (3DHPG) | 10 | [49] |
| hydroxyl and oxygen-terminated α-Fe2O3 | physical vapor deposition + dry thermal oxidation | ITO | 1 M KOH | electrocatalyst | 1.66 V vs RHE (experimental) | 0.05 | [65] |
| Ni2P nanoparticles | thermal evaporation + phosphidization | FTO | 1 M KOH | electrocatalyst | 1.63 V vs RHE | 10 | [48] |
| smooth Pt electrode | obtained as-is | standard Pt electrode | 0.5 M H2SO4 | electrocatalyst | 1.67 V vs RHE | 0.03 | [47] |
| co-treated nanoporous carbons | room-temperature chemical synthesis + carbonization at 900 °C | glassy carbon electrode | 0.1 M KOH | electrocatalyst | ∼1.6 V vs RHE (0.63 V vs Ag/AgCl) | 15 | [50] |
| TiNi molecular precursor-treated WO3 | spin coating of TiNi molecular precursor on nano-WO3 electrode | FTO | 0.1 M BK3O3 (pH 9.2) | photocatalyst | not specified | 0.43 | [52] |
| LaMnO3-carbon nanofibers | reaction under high pressure + vacuum filtration | glassy carbon disk electrode | 0.1 M KOH | electrocatalyst | 1.65 V vs RHE | 0.6 | [55] |
| graphene oxide/onion-like carbon/CNT | hydrothermal reaction: graphene oxide, onion-like carbon, and MWCNT at 180 °C | rotating disk electrode | 1 M KOH | electrocatalyst | 1.67 V vs RHE | 10 | [51] |
| B, N, S-doped GO/CoO composite | hydrothermal synthesis (B, N, S-doped carbon dots) + thermal annealing of cobalt acetate and GO at 800 °C (B, N, S-doped GO/CoO composite) | glassy carbon electrode | 0.1 M KOH | electrocatalyst | 1.58 V vs RHE | 10 | [54] |
| Co(II)-MOF | hydrothermal synthesis | FTO | 1 M Na2SO4 (pH adjusted to 10.5) | photocatalyst electrocatalyst combined (under illumination) | 1.65 V vs RHE | 5.89, 9.32, 15.21 | this work |
